content: The Act is titled the "Aviation Employee Screening and Security Enhancement Act of 2017" and includes definitions for various terms. The "Aviation Employee Screening and Security Enhancement Act of 2017" defines key terms such as Administration, Administrator, air carrier, appropriate congressional committees, and foreign air carrier. The "Aviation Employee Screening and Security Enhancement Act of 2017" defines terms like foreign air carrier, intelligence community, secured area, and security identification display area. The "Aviation Employee Screening and Security Enhancement Act of 2017" defines terms like secured area, security identification display area, and sterile area according to section 1540.5 of title 49, Code of Federal Regulations. SEC. 3. COST AND FEASIBILITY STUDY. The Administrator must conduct a cost and feasibility study on airport security measures, including secure doors, surveillance video, and advanced screening technologies for employee access points. The study will include information on secure doors, surveillance video recording, and advanced screening technologies like magnetometers, explosives detection canines, and x-ray bag screening technology for employee access points at airports. The study required under subsection (a) will include information on employee screening costs at airports that screen 100% of employees accessing secured areas. It will cover costs of entry and exit points, compare costs and effectiveness of security features, and be reviewed by the Comptroller General for quality assessment. The Comptroller General of the United States will assess the quality and reliability of the study on employee screening costs at airports. They will report the results to relevant committees within 60 days of receiving the study. SEC. 4. AIRPORT WORKER EDUCATION AND SECURITY AWARENESS. The Administrator will collaborate with various stakeholders to enhance security awareness among airport workers regarding insider threats and access controls. Additionally, credentialing standards will be assessed to ensure security practices are in place. The Administrator will assess credentialing standards with stakeholders to address insider threats to aviation security. Airport operators will be required to submit social security numbers for SIDA applications. The Administrator will require airport operators to submit social security numbers for SIDA applications to strengthen security vetting effectiveness. Applicants who do not provide their social security number may be denied access. Additionally, airport operators must include a screening notice in applications for access to a Security Identification Display Area. The Administrator will require airport operators to submit social security numbers for SIDA applications to enhance security vetting. Applicants who do not provide their social security number may be denied access. Additionally, airport operators must include a screening notice in applications for access to a Security Identification Display Area, informing employees of potential screenings. SEC. 5. SECURING AIRPORT WORKER ACCESS. The Administrator will collaborate with airport operators and the Aviation Security Advisory Committee to identify advanced technologies, including biometric identification, for securing employee access to airport secured and sterile areas. Additionally, within 180 days of the Act's enactment, all credentialed aviation workers requiring fingerprint-based criminal record checks will be continuously vetted through the FBI's Rap Back Service to detect insider threats. Furthermore, means of enhancing the Administration's ability to leverage DHS resources for insider threat education and mitigation will be identified within the same timeframe. The Administrator will enhance the Administration's ability to educate personnel on insider threats to aviation security and mitigate such threats. Playbook operations for employee physical inspections will be targeted and strategic. Covert testing of employee inspection operations will be conducted by the Administrator. The Administration conducts covert testing of employee inspection operations at airports to measure security effectiveness and provides results and recommendations to airport operators, air carriers, and foreign air carriers. The Administrator conducts covert testing of employee inspection operations at airports and provides recommendations to airport operators, air carriers, and foreign air carriers. Additionally, annual reports are submitted to congressional committees on the effectiveness of these operations. A centralized database is also established within 180 days of the Act's enactment. The Administrator conducts covert testing of employee inspection operations at airports and provides recommendations to airport operators, air carriers, and foreign air carriers. Annual reports on the effectiveness of these operations are submitted to congressional committees. A national database is established within 180 days to track individuals with revoked airport badges for non-compliance with security requirements. Reporting mechanisms for data submission and access are determined for air carriers, foreign air carriers, and airport operators. The Administrator establishes a national database to track individuals with revoked airport badges. Reporting mechanisms are determined for air carriers, foreign air carriers, and airport operators to submit data and access the database. A process is established for individuals to correct mistaken entries and have their names removed from the database. SEC. 6. The Department of Homeland Security leads insider threat coordination efforts at airports, working with other relevant entities. SEC. 7. The Administrator must submit a plan for recurring reviews of IT security controls at airports within 90 days. SEC. 8. No additional funds authorized. SEC. 7. The Administrator must submit a plan for recurring reviews of IT security controls for Administration information technology systems at airports within 90 days. SEC. 8. No additional funds authorized for carrying out the requirements of this Act.
